{{Infobox institute |name = Inclusive Design Research Centre |image = |image_name = |image_size = |image_alt = |caption = |latin_name = |motto = |founder =Jutta Treviranus<ref name=Torontoist2013>{{cite web |url=http://torontoist.com/2013/09/i-want-your-job-jutta-treviranus-director-of-the-inclusive-design-research-centre/ |title=I Want Your Job: Jutta Treviranus, Director of the Inclusive Design Research Centre |first=Kaitlyn |last=Kochany |publisher=[[Torontoist]] |date=September 25, 2013 |quote=After starting the Adaptive Technology Resource Centre at the University of Toronto in 1994, Treviranus moved it to OCADU in 2010 and rebranded it as the IDRC.|accessdate=June 3, 2014}}</ref> |established = {{Start date|September 1994 (?)}}<ref name=Torontoist2013 /><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.augcominc.com/newsletters/index.cfm/newsletter_112.pdf |work=Augmentative Communications News |date=March–April 1995 |volume=8 |number=2 |title=The Adaptive Technology Resource Centre |page=7 |quote=The Adaptive Technology Resource Centre (ATRC), located at the University of Toronto, opened in September, 1994 |accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnib.ca/en/about/awards/achievement/dmfm/pages/2005_winner.aspx |title=2005 Recipient: University of Toronto, Adaptive Technology Resource Centre (ATRC) |date=June 15, 2005 |author=[[Canadian National Institute for the Blind]] |quote=The ATRC was established in 1994 |accessdate=June 3, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606205113/http://www.cnib.ca/en/about/awards/achievement/dmfm/pages/2005_winner.aspx |archivedate=June 6, 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/digital-agenda/events/cf/ict2013/person.cfm?eventid=ict2013&personid=48386 |title=Jutta TREVIRANUS |website=European Commission: ICT 2013 |quote=With its origins in the Adaptive Technology Resource Centre established in 1993, the IDRC is….|accessdate=June 3, 2014}}</ref><ref name=OCAD-IDRC-Treviranus>{{cite web |url=http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/about-the-idrc/staff-pages/112-jutta-treviranus-director |website=Inclusive Design Research Centre, OCAD University |title=Staff Pages: Jutta Treviranus (Director) |quote=With the help of a many individuals and organizations I established the then "Adaptive Technology Resource Centre" (ATRC) in 1993 at the University of Toronto.…Thanks to talented staff, many of whom are students, the ATRC, now the Inclusive Design Research Centre at OCAD University, continues to meet these expectations.|accessdate=June 3, 2014}}</ref> |mission = |focus = [[Inclusive design]] in an [[information and communications technology]] context |parent=[[OCAD University]] |president = |chairman = |head_label = Director |head = Jutta Treviranus |faculty = |adjunct_faculty = |staff = 20<ref>{{cite web |url=http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/about-the-idrc/staff-pages |title=Staff pages |website=Inclusive Design Research Centre, OCAD University |accessdate=June 3, 2014}}</ref> |key_people = |budget = |endowment = |debt = |num_members = |subsidiaries = |owner = |non-profit_slogan = |former_name = Adaptive Technology Resource Centre<ref name=OCAD-IDRC-Treviranus /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ctl.utsc.utoronto.ca/technology/lms |title=What is a Learning Management System? |website=[[University of Toronto]] |quote=ATutor was developed by U of T's Adaptive Technology Resource Centre, which was renamed the Inclusive Design Research Centre and relocated to OCAD University August 1, 2010. |accessdate=June 3, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://raisingthefloor.org/content/jutta-treviranus-0 |title=Jutta Treviranus |author=[[Raising the Floor]] |quote=Jutta Treviranus is the Director of the Inclusive Design Research Centre (IDRC) and professor at OCAD University in Toronto, formerly the Adaptive Technology Resource Centre. |accessdate=June 3, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140607002540/http://raisingthefloor.org/content/jutta-treviranus-0 |archivedate=June 7, 2014 |df= }}</ref> |location = |city = [[Toronto]] |state = |province = [[Ontario]] |country = [[Canada]] |coor = |address = 205 Richmond Street West, Level 2 |website = {{URL|idrc.ocadu.ca}} |dissolved = |footnotes = }} The '''Inclusive Design Research Centre''' (IDRC) is a research and development centre at [[OCAD University]] in Toronto, Canada. The centre defines [[inclusive design]] as that which "considers the full range of human diversity with respect to ability, language, culture, gender, age and other forms of human difference."<ref>{{cite web|title=About the IDRC |url=http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/about-the-idrc|publisher=Inclusive Design Research Centre (OCAD University) |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> The research centre is directed by [[Jutta Treviranus]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Staff Pages |url=http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/about-the-idrc/staff-pages/112-jutta-treviranus-director|publisher=Inclusive Design Research Centre (OCAD University) |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> In 2011 the centre launched a Master of Design in Inclusive Design.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aoda.ca/ocad-u-sees-an-accessible-future-with-new-master-program-in-inclusive-design/ |title=OCAD U Sees an Accessible Future with New Master Program in Inclusive Design |first=Jaclyn |last=Law | website=Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA) |publisher=aoda.ca |date=March 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Master's Program |url=http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/workshops-aamp-trainings/masters-program |publisher=Inclusive Design Research Centre (OCAD University) |accessdate=30 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202173140/http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/workshops-aamp-trainings/masters-program |archivedate=2 February 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Current Projects==
The IDRC supports open standards, open access, and open source technology wherever possible in order to maximize distribution and to encourage broad participation. Some of the new initiatives the IDRC is working on are:
''FLOE Project: Flexible Learning for Open Education.'' FLOE is intended to enable inclusive access to personally relevant, engaging learning opportunities for the full diversity of learners and content producers. For example, Users can customize the look and feel and presentation of web content to meet their unique needs and preferences through FLOE User Interface Options. In addition, the FLOE video player allows multiple language caption support, synchronized and navigable transcripts, and is fully accessible via keyboard control, and screen reader.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.floeproject.org/ |title=Flexible Learning for Open Education |publisher= Inclusive Design Research Centre|accessdate=April 23, 2014}}</ref><ref name=new>{{cite web|title=New Projects |url=http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/research-and-development/new-projects|publisher=Inclusive Design Research Centre (OCAD University) |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref>
''ADOD Project: Accessible Digital Office Document.'' ADOD is developing vendor-neutral manual with practical application-specific instructions that can help users choose accessible office applications and create accessible documents from common office application suites. The guidance is based primarily on [[WCAG]] 2.0 and [[Web Accessibility Initiative#Authoring Tools Accessibility Guidelines .28ATAG.29|ATAG]] 1.0 recommendations of the [[W3C]]. ADOD is being developed in partnership with [[UNESCO]] and the [[Ontario Ministry of Community and Social Services]].<ref name=new/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://adod.idrc.ocad.ca/ |title=Accessible Digital Office Document (ADOD) Project |publisher= Inclusive Design Research Centre|accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref>
''AEGIS Ontario: Integrating Accessibility into Emerging ICT.'' The ÆGIS Ontario project is devoted to ensuring that emerging information and communication technologies (ICT) are designed inclusively, thereby supporting Ontario's commitment to equal access and preparing Ontario's ICT businesses to meet the growing global demand for products and services that provide accessibility to people of all abilities. The project is funded by the Ontario Research Fund Research Excellence program, and is working in close partnership with AEGIS Europe.<ref name=new/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://aegis.idrc.ocad.ca/ |title= ÆGIS Project (Ontario) |publisher= Inclusive Design Research Centre|accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref>
==Inclusive Design Institute==
The '''Inclusive Design Institute''' (IDI) is a related enterprise, housed in the same facilities as the IDRC, that serves as a regional research network for inclusive design. Also directed by Treviranus,<ref name=idi-about>{{cite web|title=Inclusive Design Institute – About – Overview|url=http://inclusivedesign.ca/about/|publisher=Inclusive Design Institute|accessdate=5 November 2012}}</ref> It was founded in 2008<ref name=idrc-news-409>{{cite web|last=Treviranus|first=Jutta|title=New Directions|url=http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/about-the-idrc/idrc-news/8-latest/409-new-directions|publisher=Inclusive Design Research Centre|accessdate=4 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813130738/http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/about-the-idrc/idrc-news/8-latest/409-new-directions#|archive-date=2011-08-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and officially launched on 24 May 2012,<ref name=cou-pr-20120524>{{cite web|title=OCAD University opens Inclusive Design Institute|url=http://cou.on.ca/news/media-releases/university/ocad-university-opens-inclusive-design-institute|publisher=Council of Ontario Universities|accessdate=5 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201182708/http://cou.on.ca/news/media-releases/university/ocad-university-opens-inclusive-design-institute|archivedate=1 February 2014|df=}}</ref> with the aim to "address the challenge of designing our information and communication systems (ICT) so that they work for all potential users, including users with disabilities, varying language needs and diverse cultural preferences."<ref name="idi-about"/> It consists of eight core postsecondary partners ([[OCAD University]], [[University of Toronto]], [[Ryerson University]], [[York University]], [[University of Ontario Institute of Technology]], [[Sheridan College]], [[George Brown College]] and [[Seneca College]]) and over 100 collaborating organizations,<ref name="idi-about"/> and is funded by the [[Canada Foundation for Innovation]] and the Ontario Ministry of Research and Innovation.<ref name=cou-pr-20101012>{{cite web|title=OCAD University welcomes the Inclusive Design Research Centre and the Inclusive Design Institute|url=http://cou.on.ca/news/media-releases/university/ocad-university-welcomes-the-inclusive-design-rese|publisher=Council of Ontario Universities|accessdate=5 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201182606/http://cou.on.ca/news/media-releases/university/ocad-university-welcomes-the-inclusive-design-rese|archivedate=1 February 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name=cfi>{{cite web|title=List of Funded Projects|url=https://www2.innovation.ca/pls/fci/FCIENREP.resultats?mecanismeSel=Tous&provSel=ON&typeEtabSel=1&etabSel=145&secteurSel=Tous&discSel=0&secteuraaSel=Tous&dom_appSel=0|publisher=Canada Foundation for Innovation|accessdate=5 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203080421/https://www2.innovation.ca/pls/fci/FCIENREP.resultats?mecanismeSel=Tous&provSel=ON&typeEtabSel=1&etabSel=145&secteurSel=Tous&discSel=0&secteuraaSel=Tous&dom_appSel=0|archivedate=3 February 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ontario Research Fund Infrastructure Program|url=http://www.mri.gov.on.ca/english/programs/orf/ri/documents/Ontario%20Research%20Fund%20-%20Research%20Infrastructure%20Projects.pdf|publisher=Ontario Ministry of Research and Innovation|accessdate=5 November 2012|page=10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831183602/http://www.mri.gov.on.ca/english/programs/orf/ri/documents/Ontario%20Research%20Fund%20-%20Research%20Infrastructure%20Projects.pdf|archivedate=31 August 2012|df=}}</ref> Thirty-five academics from the participating institutions are affiliated with the institute.<ref>{{cite web|title=Who We Are |url=http://inclusivedesign.ca/people/|publisher=Inclusive Design Institute|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
==Definition of Inclusive Design==
Some research centres that use the term "inclusive design" do so synonymously with the older field of [[universal design]]. Both inclusive design and universal design seek to design systems "... so that work for people with disabilities results in systems that work better for everyone [and] increase the human capacity to meet legal, policy and societal commitments to [[accessibility]], [[multiculturalism|diversity]] and inclusion at a local, national and global level."<ref name=IDRCDefinition/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocadu.ca/graduate-studies/programs/inclusive-design|title=Master of Design Programs|accessdate=April 14, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222215312/http://www.ocadu.ca/graduate-studies/programs/inclusive-design|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=}}</ref> The IDRC, however, presents a definition of inclusive Design that has key differences from universal design and its own distinctive features. Inclusive design principles are intended to make universal design more fully inclusive, according to the centre.<ref name=IDRCDefinition>{{cite web |url=http://idrc.ocad.ca/index.php/about-the-idrc/49-resources/online-resources/articles-and-papers/443-whatisinclusivedesign |title=IDRC Definition of Inclusive Design|accessdate=April 14, 2014}}</ref>
Universal design grew out of [[industrial design|industrial]] and [[architecture|architectural design]] whereas inclusive design came out of the [[digital marketing|digital]] world. Greater design options allow inclusive design to produce one-size-fits-one solutions in contrast to universal design that features one-size-fits-all and may exclude [[outliers]] such as the multifaceted people with various [[disabilities]].<ref name="IDRCDefinition"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inclusivedesigntoolkit.com/betterdesign2/whatis/whatis.html#p30|title=What is inclusive design? |accessdate=August 30, 2017}}</ref> Notes the IDRC: "while universal design is about creating a common design that works for everyone, we [in inclusive design] have the freedom to create a design system that can adapt, morph, or stretch to address each design need presented by each individual." <ref name=IDRCDefinition/> Researchers in inclusive design believe that every user of any system, be it digital or policy, must be recognized as unique and that "it is the responsibility of inclusive designers to be aware of the context and broader impact of any design and strive to effect a beneficial impact beyond the intended beneficiary of the design."<ref name=IDRCDefinition/>
Treviranus, the IDRC head, has led a body of research investigating and developing a new approach to accessibility: reframing disability as a mismatch between the needs of the user and the environment or system offered (and therefore not a personal trait but a consequence of the relationship between the individual and their environment).<ref name="imsglobal.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.imsglobal.org/accessibility/accmdv1p0/imsaccmd_infov1p0.html|title=IMS AccessForAll Meta-data Information Model|publisher=IMS Global Learning Consortium, Inc.|accessdate=May 30, 2014}}</ref> This technical and conceptual framework takes advantage of the plasticity of information and communications technology (ICT) systems to personally optimize the user interface to the needs and preferences of each individual.<ref name="imsglobal.org"/> This approach supports human diversity in digital systems not by attempting to find a one-size-fits-all solution but by adapting to the cluster of diverse needs of each user.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imsglobal.org/acclip/acclipv1p0/imsacclip_infov1p0.html|title=IMS Learner Information Package Accessibility for LIP Information Model|publisher=IMS Global Learning Consortium, Inc.|accessdate=May 30, 2014}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Jutta Treviranus==
Director of both the IDRC and IDI, [[Jutta Treviranus]] is a world expert in the field of inclusive design who has made appearances at the [[White House]] and [[United Nations]].<ref>{{cite web|title=I Want Your Job: Jutta Treviranus, Director of the Inclusive Design Research Centre |url=http://torontoist.com/2013/09/i-want-your-job-jutta-treviranus-director-of-the-inclusive-design-research-centre/|publisher=[[Torontoist]] |last1=Kochany|first1= Kaitlyn |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> She has "led many international multi‐partner research networks that have created broadly implemented technical innovations that support inclusion." Her work has included designing open source content and helping implement accessibility legislation, standards, and specifications.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jutta Treviranus: Background for ECM |url=https://www.un.org/disabilities/documents/egm2012/JuttaTreviranus.pdf |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
In 2013 Treviranus was awarded the [[Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal|Queen's Diamond Jubilee Medal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gg.ca/honour.aspx?id=261656&t=13&ln=Treviranus |title= The Diamond Jubilee Medal |date= 2013 |publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]] |accessdate=February 3, 2014}}</ref> In the same year, the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]] awarded Treviranus their International 1906 Award; it recognizes experts' contributions to the field.<ref>{{cite web|title=Professor Jutta Treviranus winner of International Electrotechnical Commission 1906 Award |url=http://www.scc.ca/en/news-events/news/2013/professor-jutta-treviranus-winner-international-electrotechnical-commission |publisher=Standards Council of Canada |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=1906 Award: Criteria |url=http://www.iec.ch/about/awards/1906/ |publisher=International Electrotechnical Commission |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
==Awards and distinctions== * 2011 Platinum Learning Impact Leadership Award, IMS Global Learning Consortium for A-Tutor * 2009 Delegates Web Accessibility Challenge Award, WWW/W4A Conference, Madrid for A-Tutor & AccessForAll. * 2008 Gold Learning Impact Award, IMS Global Learning Consortium for A-Tutor * 2008 Learning Impact Leadership Award, [[IMS Global Learning Consortium]] for Fluid Project * 2008 Learning Impact Leadership Award, IMS Global Learning Consortium for Transformable
==External links== * Fluid Project Wiki: [http://wiki.fluidproject.org/display/fluid/%28Floe%29+User+Interface+Options+%28aka.+Learner+Options%29 (Floe) User Interface Options (aka. Learner Options)] and [http://wiki.fluidproject.org/display/fluid/%28Floe%29+Video+Player Floe Video Player]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Sir John McNeill sculpted by Sir John Steell 1859.jpg|thumb|Sir John McNeill sculpted by Sir [[John Steell]] 1859]] [[File:Sir John_McNeill.jpg|thumb]] '''Sir John McNeill''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|GCB|PC|FRSE|FRAS|DCL|LLD}} (1795 – 17 May 1883) was a Scottish surgeon and diplomat. ==Early life== McNeill was born on 12 August 1795 at Oronsay House on the island of [[Oronsay]] in the [[Inner Hebrides]]. He was the third of the six sons of John McNeill, [[laird]] of [[Colonsay]] and [[Oronsay, Inner Hebrides|Oronsay]] (1767–1846) and his wife, Hester McNeill (died 1843). He was the younger brother of the law lord [[Duncan McNeill, 1st Baron Colonsay and Oronsay]].{{cite book |last1=Waterston |first1=Charles D |last2=Macmillan Shearer |first2=A |title=Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002: Biographical Index |url=http://www.rse.org.uk/fellowship/fells_indexp2.pdf |accessdate=25 September 2010 |volume=II |date=July 2006 |publisher=[[The Royal Society of Edinburgh]] |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-0-902198-84-5 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611234324/http://www.rse.org.uk/fellowship/fells_indexp2.pdf |archivedate=11 June 2009 |df= }} ==Education== He studied medicine at the [[University of Edinburgh]], where he graduated as a [[Doctor of Medicine]] in 1814, at the age of nineteen.{{sfn|Chichester|1893}} ==Career== ===India=== On 6 September 1816 he was appointed assistant surgeon on the [[Honourable East India Company]]'s Bombay establishment. He was moved to [[Persia]] in 1819. He received his licence as a surgeon on 1 May 1824 and retired from the medical service on 4 June 1836, thereafter concentrating on the diplomatic aspects of the East India Company.{{sfn|Chichester|1893}}{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}} He was attached to the field force under Colonel East in [[Kutch]] and [[Okamundel]] in 1818–19 and was afterwards deputy medical storekeeper at the presidency.{{sfn|Chichester|1893}} ===Persia=== From 1824 to 1835, he was attached to the East India Company's legation in [[Persia]], at first in medical charge, and latterly as political assistant to the Minister, [[John Macdonald Kinneir]], in which post he displayed great ability. For instance, in 1829 he was probably one of the instigators of the murder of [[Alexander Griboyedov]] by Persian mob in [[Teheran]]. On 30 June 1835, he was appointed secretary of the special embassy sent to [[Tehran]] under [[Henry Ellis (diplomat)|Henry Ellis]] to congratulate [[Mohammad Shah Qajar]] on his accession to the Persian throne. McNeill received permission to wear the Persian [[Order of the Lion and the Sun]] of the first class, and on his return home in the spring of 1836, he anonymously published a startling anti-Russian pamphlet, ''Progress and Present Position of Russia in the East''. From 1836 to 1844, McNeill was any envoy to Persia. See [[Siege of Herat (1838)|Siege of Herat]]. ===Scotland=== In 1845, McNeill was appointed chairman of the [[Board of Supervision]], entrusted with the working of the new [[Poor Law (Scotland) Act 1845]], a post he occupied for twenty-three years. During the [[Highland Potato Famine]] – nearly as disastrous as the [[Irish Potato Famine]] – he conducted a special inquiry into the condition of the western [[Scottish Highlands]] and [[Western Isles]], during which he personally inspected twenty-seven of the most distressed parishes. During his stay in Scotland he lived at [[Granton, Edinburgh|Granton]] House in [[Edinburgh]].Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1850-1 He was cofounder in 1851, with [[Sir_Charles_Trevelyan,_1st_Baronet|Sir Charles Trevelyan]], of the [[Highland and Island Emigration Society]] which during the [[Highland Clearances]] supported an exodus of nearly 5,000 people to Australia between 1851 and 1856. Devine, T. M. ''To the Ends of the Earth: Scotland's Global Diaspora'', Allen Lane, 1 August 2011, Chapter 5, Section 2. ===Crimean War=== At the outbreak the [[Crimean War]] in 1854, McNeill published revised editions in French and English of his pamphlet ''Progress and Present Position of Russia in the East'', with supplementary chapters dealing with the progress of events since 1836, and insisting on the importance to Britain and to [[Christendom]] of the autonomy of [[Turkey]] and Persia. At the beginning of 1855, when the Crimean disasters had roused public indignation, McNeill and Colonel [[Alexander Tulloch]], an officer of great administrative experience at the [[War Office]], were sent to the Crimea with instructions to report on the whole arrangements and management of the [[commissariat]] and the method of keeping accounts, and to the causes of the delays in unloading and distributing clothing and other stores sent to [[Balaklava]]. The commissioners started at once for the seat of war. They took no [[shorthand]] writer with them, as the remuneration sanctioned by the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]] was insufficient to secure a qualified person. The McNeill–Tulloch inquiry was the most effective of the various inquisitions into the Crimean débâcle. It sharply criticised [[FitzRoy Somerset, 1st Baron Raglan|Lord Raglan's]] personal staff in the Crimea and Commissary-General Filder, and it led to many recriminations as officers sought to clear their names when the report was published in 1856. A board of general officers was convened to clear the army, but despite its protestations, the McNeill–Tulloch report led to professional reform of the commissariat by the [[Royal warrant (document)|Royal Warrant]] of October 1858. Very unusually, the [[British House of Commons|Commons]], irritated by executive obfuscation, passed a resolution in 1857 calling for special honours and McNeill soon became a [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Councillor]] and Tulloch was appointed a [[Order of the Bath|KCB]]. The [[University of Oxford]] made McNeill a [[Doctor of Civil Law]] and the University of Edinburgh chose him as chairman of its amalgamated societies; his inaugural address on competitive examinations was published in 1861. ==Personal life== [[File:Memorial to Sir John McNeill and Lady Emma Augusta McNeill, Liberton Cemetery, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|Memorial to Sir John McNeill and Lady Emma Augusta McNeill, [[Liberton, Edinburgh|Liberton Cemetery, Edinburgh]]]] McNeill married, firstly, in 1814, Innes Robinson, fourth daughter of George Robinson of [[Clermiston]], Midlothian – she died in 1816; secondly, in 1823, Eliza Wilson, third daughter of John Wilson – she died in 1868; thirdly, in 1871, Lady Emma Augusta Campbell, daughter of [[John Campbell, 7th Duke of Argyll]].{{sfn|Chichester|1893}} McNeill was the brother-in law (by his 2nd marriage) of the author [[John Wilson (Scottish writer)|John Wilson]], and (by his 3rd marriage) of [[George Campbell, 8th Duke of Argyll]]. McNeill died at Poralto near [[Cannes]] in [[France]], on 17 May 1883.{{sfn|Chichester|1893}} A memorial to his memory lies on the south-east wall of Liberton Cemetery in Edinburgh, at the grave of his third wife, Emma Augusta. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{DNB|wstitle=MacNeill, John|first=Henry Manners |last=Chichester|volume=35}} {{start box}} {{s-dip}} {{succession box | title=[[List of diplomats from the United Kingdom to Iran|Minister to Persia]] | before=[[Henry Ellis (diplomat)|Henry Ellis]] | after=No representation due
to the [[Siege of Herat (1838)|Siege of Herat]] | years=1836–1838}} {{succession box | title=[[List of diplomats from the United Kingdom to Iran|Minister to Persia]] | before=Relations restored | after=[[Justin Sheil]] | years=1841–1844}} {{end box}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McNeill, John}} [[Category:Scottish diplomats]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Asiatic Society]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Members of the Privy Council of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Lion and the Sun]] [[Category:1795 births]] [[Category:1883 deaths]] [[Category:People from Argyll and Bute]] [[Category:Scottish surgeons]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish civil servants]] [[Category:The Great Game]] [[Category:19th-century British diplomats]]

revision.comment: /* Charity background and aftermath */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: three story → three-story (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Ladies' Deborah and Child's Protectory''' was a 19th-century [[day care center]] and orphanage located at 204 [[East Broadway (Manhattan)|East Broadway]]. The institution cared for the children, ages two to six years, of indigent parents who worked during the day. The youths were fed and returned to their parents in the evening.<ref name=new/> Abandoned children were also taken in. A [[certificate of incorporation]] was filed at the clerk's office of [[New York County]] on March 5, 1878.<ref>''City And Suburban News'', New York Times, March 6, 1878, pg. 8.</ref>
The facility opened on the morning of March 24, 1878, when fifty-nine small children were received inside. Ladies' Deborah and Child's Protectory was established by Mrs. P.J. Joachimsen.<ref name=new>''[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E0CE2DA163FE036A05756C2A9659C946990D7CF&legacy=true A New Charitable Institution]'', [[New York Times]], March 25, 1878, pg. 8.</ref> She was president of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society of [[New York City]].<ref>''[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9901EEDE1038E033A25752C1A9669D94659FD7CF&legacy=true Hebrew Charity For Children]'', New York Times, October 11, 1884, pg. 8.</ref>
In January 1880 the New York City Board of Apportionment distributed $1,289.43 from the [[excise]] fund to assist in the support of children at the institution, which was then being called Ladies' Deborah Nursery and Child's Protectory.<ref>''Disposing Of The Excise Fund'', New York Times, January 8, 1880, pg. 3.</ref>
In March 1883 the Deborah Nursery was located at 95 East Broadway, with a branch at 101 East Broadway and a girls' branch at 423 East 83rd Street. [[Elbridge T. Gerry]], president of the New York Society of Prevention of Cruelty to Children, listed the buildings of the three sites as worthy of attention by the building department, in regard to repairs.<ref>''[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B06E4DB1731E433A25752C3A9659C94629FD7CF&legacy=true Buildings Which Require Attention]'', New York Times, March 31, 1883, pg. 8.</ref>
==Child abuse and poor management== {{See also|Child abuse}} Israel Schwartz, a thirteen-year-old [[Jewish people|Jewish]] boy, accused superintendent Herman Engel, of the nursery, of assaulting him with a cane, in May 1893. Engel was held for examination and fined $300. Schwartz complaint was one of many which were reported around this time.<ref>''Mr. Engel Must Explain'', New York Times, June 1, 1893, pg. 9.</ref>
In November 1896 the facility was ordered to promptly make reforms by the [[New York City Board of Health]]. At this instance the nursery was afflicted by the prevalence of [[ophthalmia]]. In March 1896 eighty cases of the disease were reported among the children at Ladies' Deborah Nursery and Child's Protectorate. Infected children were quarantined but twenty-two of them were released back to the main building, despite continuing to suffer from various forms of eye diseases. The institution was then located at Eagle Avenue and 161st Street in Manhattan.<ref>''[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990CE7DD1331E033A2575BC1A9679D94679ED7CF&legacy=true A Bad State Of Things]'', New York Times, November 18, 1896, pg. 12.</ref>
==Charity background and aftermath==
The Ladies' Deborah Relief Association was active at least four years before the opening of the child's protectory. On July 29, 1874 the organization held a benefit for the sick and poor at Bellevue Garden near [[80th Street (Manhattan)]].<ref>''[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B00E1D81139EF34BC4051DFB166838F669FDE&legacy=true City And Suburban News]'', New York Times, July 28, 1874, pg. 8.</ref>
In June 1897 the Eagle Avenue site, on the [[West Side (Manhattan)]], was sold during a foreclosure. The lot measured 150 feet by 125 feet and possessed a three-story and a four-story building, both composed of brick. $18,687 was due on judgment.<ref>''[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F0DE6D91630E132A25754C2A9609C94669ED7CF&legacy=true Auction Sales This Week]'', New York Times, June 27, 1897, pg. 4.</ref>
==References== <references/>
* {{cite web|url=http://www.soloff.com/hnoh/USJORPH6B.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323014933/http://www.soloff.com/hnoh/USJORPH6B.html|title=LADY DEBORAH NURSERY & CHILD PROTECTORY|archivedate=23 March 2012|author=Florence Marmor |author2= Marge Spears-Soloff|publisher=soloff.com|date=1999|accessdate=13 February 2018|deadurl=unfit}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ladies' Deborah And Child's Protectory}} [[Category:1878 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:History of New York City]] [[Category:Social welfare charities based in the United States]] [[Category:Social care in the United States]] [[Category:Jewish organizations]] [[Category:Orphanages in the United States]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in Manhattan]] [[Category:Jewish orphanages]]

revision.text:
[[File:Pasang.jpg|thumb|Statue honoring the woman [[Pasang Lhamu Sherpa]], the first Nepali woman to summit but did not make it down alive]] '''List of Mount Everest death statistics''' is a list of statistics about death on [[Mount Everest]]. For a list of mountaineer deaths on Mount Everest, see [[List of people who died climbing Mount Everest]]
==Youngest people to die on Mount Everest== ''Examples of known cases''<ref name="ExWeb">{{cite web|url=http://www.explorersweb.com/everest_k2/news.php?url=everest-names-of-avalanche-victims_1430306452|title=Everest K2 News ExplorersWeb - Everest: List of Avalanche Victims|publisher=|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="advc-everest">{{cite web|url=http://www.humanedgetech.com/expedition/ac111/|title=Adventure Consultants Everest 2015 - Dispatches - By CONTACT5.0|author=Human Edge Tech, Explorersweb Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref name= "Ortner p. 49">{{harvnb|Ortner|2001|p=49}}</ref>
*Pemba Sherpa, April 25, 2015, 19<ref name="ExWeb"/><ref name="advc-everest"/><ref name="adventureconsultants 2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.adventureconsultants.com/adventure/Everest_Dispatch2015/|title=Adventure Consultants Everest 2015 Expedition Dispatches|publisher=adventureconsultants.com|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> *Ang Chuldim, August 31, 1982, 20<ref name= "Reuter1982 p. 3">{{harvnb|Reuter|1982|p=3}}</ref> *Lobsang Sherpa, May 7, 2013, 22<ref name="nst">{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/latest/young-sherpa-plunges-to-his-death-on-everest-1.274463 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615141146/http://www.nst.com.my/latest/young-sherpa-plunges-to-his-death-on-everest-1.274463 |archive-date=15 June 2013 |dead-url=yes |title=Young Sherpa plunges to his death on Everest - Latest - New Straits Times |accessdate=28 May 2016 |df= }}</ref> *Víctor Hugo Trujillo, August 16, 1986, 22<ref name= "Bell p. ">{{harvnb|Bell|1986|p=}}</ref> *[[Andrew Irvine (mountaineer)|Andrew Irvine]], June 9, 1924, 22<ref name= "Ortner p. 49"/> *[[Marco Siffredi]], September 8, 2002, 23 <ref name= "Smith p. ">{{harvnb|Smith|2002|p=}}</ref> *Michael Matthews, May 13, 1999, 23<ref name= "Douglas p. ">{{harvnb|Douglas|2001|p=}}</ref>
==Named corpses== [[File:Green Boots.jpg|thumb|Photo of Green Boots taken by Everest climber.|The corpse known as Green Boots in its eponymous Everest cave]] *"The German Woman", [[Hannelore Schmatz]]<ref name=dwhelga>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.dw.com/abenteuersport/helga-hengge-everest-english/ |title=Helga’s Everest nightmare - In English - Abenteuer Sport - DW.COM|publisher=blogs.dw.com|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> *"[[Green Boots]]", possibly [[Tsewang Paljor]]<ref name=britbc/> *"Sleeping Beauty", [[Francys Arsentiev]]<ref name=britbc>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20151008-the-graveyard-in-the-clouds-everests-200-dead-bodies |title=BBC - Future - Death in the clouds: The problem with Everest’s 200+ bodies |date= 9 October 2015|author=Rachel Nuwer|publisher=bbc.com|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref>
==Medical and scientific professionals who died on Everest== See also Dr. [[Beck Weathers]], a medical doctor who is famous for narrowly surviving the 1996 Everest Disaster.<ref>http://www.dallasnews.com/news/metro/20150916-new-life-for-dallas-doctor-came-from-near-death-on-everest.ece</ref>
*Dr. [[A. M. Kellas]] (1921, en route to Everest as part of expedition)<ref name= "Ortner p. 49" /><ref name= "Ortner p. 31">{{harvnb|Ortner|2001|p=31}}</ref> *[[Karl Gordon Henize|Dr. Karl G. Henize]] (PhD in astronomy)(1993)<ref name="nytimes.com">[https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/10/obituaries/karl-g-henize-nasa-scientist-dies-at-66-climbing-mount-everest.html]</ref> *Dr. Sándor Gárdos (2001), Hungarian team doctor, specialist of high altitude medicine <ref>http://mecslaszlo.blogspot.hu/2011/10/gardos-sandor-dr.html</ref> *Dr. Nils Antezana (2004, pathologist)<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A9241-2004Nov24.html]</ref> *Dr. Robert Milne (2005, Phd worked on software)<ref>[http://www.aiai.ed.ac.uk/project/everest/external-cache/EverestNews-Report.htm]</ref> *Dr. Eberhard Schaaf (2012), German doctor died high on Everest.<ref>[http://www.outsideonline.com/1914501/climbings-little-helper]</ref> *Dr. Charles MacAdams (2016)<ref name="legacy.com">[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/vancouversun/obituary.aspx?pid=180046324]</ref> *Dr. Maria Strydom (2016)<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/25/mount-everest-climbers-death-toll-rises-to-five/]</ref> *Dr. Peter Kinloch had completed a Phd. died in 2010 on M. Everest<ref>[http://news.sky.com/story/782817/climber-dies-on-everest-after-going-blind]</ref> *Dr. Roland Yearwood (2017), a medical doctor in Alabama (USA) died in 2017 on Everest.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/body-of-indian-climber-spotted-on-everest-as-weeks-death-toll-rises-to-4/2017/05/22/9028017a-3f12-11e7-9869-bac8b446820a_story.html|title=Body of Indian climber spotted on Everest as weekend’s death toll rises to 4|website=Washington Post|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref>
==Died on descent after summiting== [[Image:Memorial of Murato on Pelister.JPG|300px|thumb|Memorial of Dimitar Ilievski, who died descending from the Mountain]] Examples of those who, after summiting, died on the descent down or soon after (not counting other climbs, on the same expedition but does not have to be their first summit)
''examples only'' *[[Dimitar Ilievski-Murato]] *[[Francys Arsentiev]] *[[Hannelore Schmatz]] *[[Hristo Prodanov]] *[[Jozef Psotka]] *[[Lobsang Tshering]] *[[Marco Siffredi]] *[[Pasang Lhamu Sherpa]] *[[Ray Genet]] *Shoko Ota (2004)<ref name="cjonline">{{cite web|url=http://cjonline.com/stories/052104/pag_everest.shtml#.V0OH4l5dgnc|title=Woman dies after ascending Everest | CJOnline.com|publisher=cjonline.com|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> *[[Shriya Shah-Klorfine]] (2012) *[[Tomas Olsson]] *[[Vitor Negrete]] *[[Yasuko Namba]]
==Deadliest events at Everest== The history of mountaineering expeditions on Mount Everest has evolved since the first official mountaineering expedition trekked up its slopes in 1921. In the subsequent decades from this point until the 1960s, many expeditions were funded by major organizations and launched in a "siege"-style with large climbing parties. These early campaigns helped overcome the relatively remote nature and uncharted territory of Everest. Additionally, these journeys paved the way for the "lightweight"-style expeditions that would follow (a prime example is the successful 1980 solo ascent by [[Reinhold Messner]], the first without [[supplemental oxygen]]). The 80s and 90s saw the emergence and rise in the commercialization of the ascent to Everest's summit. These commercial expeditions range from logistics only (i.e. a permit and some basic base camp supplies) to expensive, professionally-guided expeditions promising even laypeople an increased chance of successfully reaching the summit. The increased access now afforded to scaling the [[world's tallest mountain]], while leading to more people successfully reaching the summit than ever before, has also seen a concomitant and exponential rise in casualties.
{| class="wikitable sortable" !Died !Date !Notes / Ref |- |18-22 |2015 |[[2015 Mount Everest avalanches]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/Avalanche-triggered-by-quake-kills-18-on-Mount-Everest/articleshow/47055195.cms |title=Avalanche triggered by quake kills 18 on Mount Everest |accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref> |- |16 |2014 |[[2014 Mount Everest avalanche]]<ref name=NYr>{{cite news|last=Krakauer|first=Jon|title=Death and Anger on Everest|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2014/04/everest-sherpas-death-and-anger.html|accessdate=22 April 2014|newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]|date=21 April 2014|quote=Of the twenty-five men hit by the falling ice, sixteen were killed, all of them Nepalis working for guided climbing teams.}}</ref> |- |8-12 |1996 |[[1996 Mount Everest disaster]] |- |6 |1974 |[[1974 French Mount Everest expedition|1974 French Mount Everest expedition avalanche]]<ref name=WestRidge1>{{cite web|title=The West Ridge Direct|url=http://www.everesthistory.com/climbers/stremfeli.htm|publisher=everesthistory.com|accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref> |- |6 |1970 |[[1970 Mount Everest disaster]] |} Another very deadly event was in 1995, when 42 died near Everest in a large avalanche.<ref name="bt">{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/news-asia/2014/04/19/12-guides-killed-worst-ever-mt-everest-accident|title=12 guides killed in worst ever Mt Everest accident | The Brunei Times|publisher=bt.com.bn|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="reuters">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSL3115818 |title=FACTBOX - World's deadliest mountaineering disasters 2008 |author=Reuters Editorial|publisher=reuters.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref>
== Deaths by nationality ==
''*with at least two deaths''
{| class="wikitable" |+ !Nationality !Count |- | {{flagcountry|NEP}} |111 |- |{{flagcountry|India}} |19 |- | {{flagcountry|Japan}} |19 |- | {{flagcountry|United Kingdom}} |17 |- | {{flagcountry|United States}} |15 |- | {{flagcountry|China}} |12 |- | {{flagcountry|South Korea}} |11 |- | {{flagcountry|Australia}} |7 |- | {{flagcountry|Germany}} |7 |- | {{flagcountry|Poland}} |7 |- | {{flagcountry|Russia}} |7 |- | {{flagcountry|Canada}} |6 |- | {{flagcountry|France}} |6 |- | {{flagcountry|Czechoslovakia}} |5 |- | {{flagcountry|Spain}} |4 |- | {{flagcountry|Bulgaria}} |3 |- | {{flagcountry|Italy}} |3 |- | {{flagcountry|New Zealand}} |3 |- | {{flagcountry|Switzerland}} |3 |- | {{flagcountry|Austria}} |2 |- | {{flagcountry|Czech Republic}} |2 |- | {{flagcountry|Denmark}} |2 |- | {{flagcountry|Hungary}} |2 |- | {{flagcountry|Slovenia}} |2 |- | {{flagcountry|Taiwan}} |2 |- | {{flagcountry|Yugoslavia}} |2 |- | {{flagcountry|Brazil}} |1 |- | Other/Unknown |12 |}
== Cause of death == {| class="wikitable" |+ !Cause !Count |- |[[Avalanche]] |68 |- |[[Falling (accident)|Fall]] |67 |- |Exposure |27 |- |[[Altitude sickness]] |21 |- |[[Cardiac arrest]] |11 |- |Exhaustion and/or exposure |8 |- |[[Fatigue (medical)|Exhaustion]] |7 |- |[[Serac]] |6 |- |[[Cerebral edema|Cerebral Oedema]] |7 |- |[[Stroke]] |2 |- |Frost Bite |1 |- |'''''Other''''' |15 |- |'''''Unknown Cause''''' |52 |}
==Astronaut fatality== [[File:Henize.jpg|thumb|Henize had been in space (see [[STS-51-F]] space mission) and co-authored many science papers]] One of the people claimed by Everest mountaineering was the U.S. astronaut [[Karl Gordon Henize]]. He was on a mission to study radiation but came down with a fatal case of [[High-altitude pulmonary edema|HAPE]] in October 1993 and died at north base camp.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> At the time he was the oldest astronaut to have flown in space and also had a doctorate in astronomy.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> He died on October 5, 1993 and was buried on Mount Everest.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-karl-henize-1512511.html]</ref>
==See also== * [[List of Mount Everest records]] * [[List of people who died climbing Mount Everest]] * [[2014 Nepal snowstorm disaster]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Deaths on Mount Everest]] [[Category:Death-related lists|Mount Everest]]

revision.text:
This '''list of chiropractic schools''' is organized alphabetically by country. In those countries with functioning, specialized, accrediting agencies, the colleges holding "recognized", or "accredited" status are delineated. Other countries and regions are in the process of developing similar programs of accreditation; and, in Switzerland, [[chiropractic]] is so fully integrated into the health care system that the existence of a separate accrediting agency is thus obviated. The course is taught in university, on the same basis as human medicine. In 2015, nine internationally accredited chiropractic colleges: AECC, WIOC, IFEC-Paris, IFEC-Toulouse, SDU-Odense, UZ-Zurich, UJ-Johannesburg, Durbin University of Technology and Macquarie University, Australia, made an open statement which included: "The teaching of the vertebral subluxation complex as a vitalistic construct that claims that it is the cause of disease is unsupported by evidence. Its inclusion in a modern chiropractic curriculum in anything other than an historic context is therefore inappropriate and unnecessary". This document is based upon and supports the theme of the World Federation of Chiropractic Educational Statement formulated in November 2014 at the Miami Education Conference.{{cite web|url=http://9564e6cf93ec0c618a68-4f22a039f96a487025fe8e71cbbe8130.r40.cf3.rackcdn.com/Undergraduate/MChiro/Educational%20Statements.pdf |format=PDF |title=The European-South African Education Collaboration : Clinical and Professional Chiropractic Education: a Position Statement |website=9564e6cf93ec0c618a68-4f22a039f96a487025fe8e71cbbe8130.r40.cf3.rackcdn.com |accessdate=2017-04-18}} ==Schools== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- style="text-align:center; background:#d6d6d6;" !Country!!'''Chiropractic institution'''!! Status !! [[File:Countries by plum and sloe production in 2016.png|thumb|600px|Countries by plum and sloe production in 2016]] [[File:2005plums and sloes.PNG|thumb|550px|A map of world plum and sloe production, 2005.]] This is a '''list of countries by [[plum]] and [[Prunus spinosa|sloe]] production''' in 2016, based on data from the [[Food and Agriculture Organization Corporate Statistical Database]].{{citeweb|website=FAOSTAT|title=Crops|url=http://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/QC/|access-date=2018-08-14}} Countries - Select All; Regions - World + (Total); Elements - Production Quantity; Items - Plums and sloes; Years - 2016 The total world production of plum and sloe for 2016 was 12,050,800 [[Tonne|metric tonnes]]. == >100,000 tonnes == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- bgcolor="#ececec" ! Rank !! Country/Region !! Plum and sloe production

page.title: Long-term impact of alcohol on the brain

revision.comment: ce
revision.text:
While researchers have found that moderate alcohol consumption in older adults is associated with better cognition and well-being than abstinence,<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1093/ageing/afm001 | pmid = 17353234 | title = Moderate alcohol consumption in older adults is associated with better cognition and well-being than abstinence | journal = Age and Ageing | volume = 36 | issue = 3 | pages = 256–61 | year = 2007 | last1 = Lang | first1 = I. | last2 = Wallace | first2 = R. B. | last3 = Huppert | first3 = F. A. | last4 = Melzer | first4 = D. }} {{open access}}</ref> excessive alcohol consumption is associated with widespread and significant brain [[lesion]]s. The effects can manifest much later—mid-life Alcohol Use Disorder has been found to correlate with increased risk of severe cognitive and memory deficits in later life.<ref name="Cassels2014">{{Cite journal|author=Caroline Cassels|date=July 30, 2014| title=Midlife Alcohol Abuse Linked to Severe Memory Impairment| journal=Medscape|publisher=WebMD LLC| url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/829073}}</ref><ref name="Kuzma2014">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.jagp.2014.06.001| title = History of Alcohol Use Disorders and Risk of Severe Cognitive Impairment: A 19-Year Prospective Cohort Study| journal = The American Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry| volume = 22| issue = 10| pages = 1047–1054| year = 2014| last1 = Kuźma | first1 = E. B. | last2 = Llewellyn | first2 = D. J. | last3 = Langa | first3 = K. M. | last4 = Wallace | first4 = R. B. | last5 = Lang | first5 = I. A. }}</ref> Alcohol related brain damage is not only due to the direct toxic effects of alcohol; alcohol withdrawal, nutritional deficiency, electrolyte disturbances, and liver damage are also believed to contribute to alcohol-related brain damage.<ref name="Neiman-1998">{{Cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1530-0277.1998.tb04389.x|last1=Neiman|first1=J.|title=Alcohol as a risk factor for brain damage: neurologic aspects|journal=Alcohol Clin. Exp. Res.|volume=22|issue=7 Suppl|pages=346S–351S|date=Oct 1998|pmid=9799959}}</ref>
==Adolescent brain development== Consuming large amounts of alcohol over a period of time can impair normal brain development in humans.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Tapert SF, Brown GG, Kindermann SS, Cheung EH, Frank LR, Brown SA |title=fMRI measurement of brain dysfunction in alcohol-dependent young women|journal=[[Alcohol. Clin. Exp. Res.]]|volume=25|issue=2|pages=236–45|date=February 2001|pmid=11236838 |doi=10.1111/j.1530-0277.2001.tb02204.x|url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/resolve/openurl?genre=article&sid=nlm:pubmed&issn=0145-6008&date=2001&volume=25&issue=2&spage=236}}</ref> Deficits in retrieval of verbal and nonverbal information and in visuospatial functioning were evident in youths with histories of heavy drinking during early and middle adolescence.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Squeglia LM, Jacobus J, Tapert SF |title=The influence of substance use on adolescent brain development|journal=Clin EEG Neurosci|volume=40|issue=1|pages=31–8|date=January 2009|pmid=19278130|pmc=2827693|doi=10.1177/155005940904000110}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Brown SA, Tapert SF, Granholm E, Delis DC |title=Neurocognitive functioning of adolescents: effects of protracted alcohol use|journal=[[Alcohol Clin. Exp. Res.]]|volume=24|issue=2|pages=164–71|date=February 2000|pmid=10698367|doi=10.1111/j.1530-0277.2000.tb04586.x|url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/resolve/openurl?genre=article&sid=nlm:pubmed&issn=0145-6008&date=2000&volume=24&issue=2&spage=164}}</ref>
During adolescence critical stages of neurodevelopment occur, including remodeling and functional changes in [[synaptic plasticity]] and neuronal connectivity in different brain regions. These changes may make adolescents especially susceptible to the harmful effects of alcohol. Compared to adults, adolescents exposed to alcohol are more likely to exhibit cognitive deficits (including learning and memory dysfunction). Some of these cognitive effects, such as learning impairments, may persist into adulthood.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Guerri | first1 = C. | last2 = Pascual | first2 = M. A. | doi = 10.1016/j.alcohol.2009.10.003 | title = Mechanisms involved in the neurotoxic, cognitive, and neurobehavioral effects of alcohol consumption during adolescence | journal = Alcohol | volume = 44 | issue = 1 | pages = 15–26 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20113871 }}</ref>
==Mechanisms of action==
===Neuroinflammation=== Ethanol can trigger the activation of [[astrocyte|astroglial cells]] which can produce a proinflammatory response in the brain. Ethanol interacts with the [[TLR4]] and [[Interleukin 1 receptor, type I|IL-1RI]] receptors on these cells to activate intracellular signal transduction pathways. Specifically, ethanol induces the phosphorylation of IL-1R-associated kinase (IRAK), [[Extracellular signal-regulated kinases|ERK1/2]], stress-activated protein kinase (SAPK)/[[c-Jun N-terminal kinases|JNK]], and [[p38 mitogen-activated protein kinases|p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (p38 MAPK)]]. Activation of the IRAK/MAPK pathway leads to the stimulation of the [[transcription factor]]s [[NF-kappaB]] and [[AP-1 transcription factor|AP-1]]. These transcription factors cause the upregulation of [[Nitric oxide synthase|inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS)]] and [[PTGS2|cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2)]] expression.<ref name="pmid16272348">{{Cite journal | author = Blanco Am | first = V. S. S. | first2 = S. L. | last3 = Pascual | first3 = M. | last4 = Guerri | first4 = C. | title = Involvement of TLR4/type I IL-1 receptor signaling in the induction of inflammatory mediators and cell death induced by ethanol in cultured astrocytes | journal = Journal of Immunology | volume = 175 | issue = 10 | pages = 6893–6899 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16272348 | doi=10.4049/jimmunol.175.10.6893 | last2 = Vallés }}</ref> The upregulation of these inflammatory mediators by ethanol is also associated with an increase in [[caspase 3]] activity and a corresponding increase in cell [[apoptosis]].<ref name="pmid16272348"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pascual | first1 = M. | last2 = Blanco | first2 = A. M. | last3 = Cauli | first3 = O. | last4 = Miñarro | first4 = J. | last5 = Guerri | first5 = C. | doi = 10.1111/j.1460-9568.2006.05298.x | title = Intermittent ethanol exposure induces inflammatory brain damage and causes long-term behavioural alterations in adolescent rats | journal = European Journal of Neuroscience | volume = 25 | issue = 2 | pages = 541–550 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17284196 }}</ref> The exact mechanism by which various concentrations of ethanol either activates or inhibits TLR4/IL-1RI signaling is not currently known, though it may involve alterations in [[lipid raft]] clustering <ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Fernandez-Lizarbe | first1 = S. | last2 = Pascual | first2 = M. | last3 = Gascon | first3 = M. S. | last4 = Blanco | first4 = A. | last5 = Guerri | first5 = C. | doi = 10.1016/j.molimm.2007.10.025 | title = Lipid rafts regulate ethanol-induced activation of TLR4 signaling in murine macrophages | journal = Molecular Immunology | volume = 45 | issue = 7 | pages = 2007–2016 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18061674 }}</ref> or [[cell adhesion]] complexes and actin [[cytoskeleton]] organization.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Guasch | first1 = R. M. | last2 = Tomas | first2 = M. | last3 = Miñambres | first3 = R. | last4 = Valles | first4 = S. | last5 = Renau-Piqueras | first5 = J. | last6 = Guerri | first6 = C. | doi = 10.1002/jnr.10594 | title = RhoA and lysophosphatidic acid are involved in the actin cytoskeleton reorganization of astrocytes exposed to ethanol | journal = Journal of Neuroscience Research | volume = 72 | issue = 4 | pages = 487–502 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12704810 }}</ref>
===Changes in dopaminergic and glutamatergic signaling pathways=== Intermittent ethanol treatment causes a decrease in expression of the [[dopamine receptor]] type 2 (D2R) and a decrease in phosphorylation of 2B subunit of the [[NMDA receptor]] (NMDAR2B) in the [[prefrontal cortex]], [[hippocampus]], [[nucleus accumbens]], and for only D2R the [[striatum]]. It also causes changes in the acetylation of [[histone]]s H3 and H4 in the prefrontal cortex, nucleus accumbens, and striatum, suggesting [[chromatin]] remodeling changes which may mediate long-term alterations. Additionally, adolescent rats pre-exposed to ethanol have higher basal levels of dopamine in the nucleus accumbens, along with a prolonged dopamine response in this area in response to a challenge dose of ethanol. Together, these results suggest that alcohol exposure during adolescence can sensitize the [[Mesolimbic pathway|mesolimbic]] and [[Mesocortical pathway|mesocortical]] dopamine pathways to cause changes in [[dopaminergic]] and glutamatergic signaling, which may affect the remodeling and functions of the adolescent brain.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pascual | first1 = M. | last2 = Boix | first2 = J. | last3 = Felipo | first3 = V. | last4 = Guerri | first4 = C. | title = Repeated alcohol administration during adolescence causes changes in the mesolimbic dopaminergic and glutamatergic systems and promotes alcohol intake in the adult rat | doi = 10.1111/j.1471-4159.2008.05835.x | journal = Journal of Neurochemistry | volume = 108 | issue = 4 | pages = 920–931 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19077056 }}</ref> These changes are significant as alcohol’s effect on NMDARs could contribute to learning and memory dysfunction (''see [[Effects of alcohol on memory#Effects on nervous system|Effects of alcohol on memory]]'').
===Inhibition of hippocampal neurogenesis=== Excessive alcohol intake ([[binge drinking]]) causes a decrease in hippocampal [[neurogenesis]], via decreases in neural stem cell proliferation and newborn cell survival.<ref name="pmid19554644">{{Cite journal | last1 = Morris | first1 = S. A. | last2 = Eaves | first2 = D. W. | last3 = Smith | first3 = A. R. | last4 = Nixon | first4 = K. | title = Alcohol inhibition of neurogenesis: A mechanism of hippocampal neurodegeneration in an adolescent alcohol abuse model | doi = 10.1002/hipo.20665 | journal = Hippocampus | volume = 20 | issue = 5 | pages = 596–607 | pmc = 2861155 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19554644 }}</ref><ref name="pmid20534463">{{Cite journal | last1 = Taffe | first1 = M. A. | last2 = Kotzebue | first2 = R. W. | last3 = Crean | first3 = R. D. | last4 = Crawford | first4 = E. F. | last5 = Edwards | first5 = S. | last6 = Mandyam | first6 = C. D. | title = Long-lasting reduction in hippocampal neurogenesis by alcohol consumption in adolescent nonhuman primates | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0912810107 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 107 | issue = 24 | pages = 11104–11109 | pmc = 2890755 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20534463 }}</ref> Alcohol decreases the number of cells in S-phase of the [[cell cycle]], and may arrest cells in the G1 phase, thus inhibiting their proliferation.<ref name="pmid19554644"/> Ethanol has different effects on different types of actively dividing hippocampal progenitors during their initial phases of neuronal development. Chronic alcohol exposure decreases the number of proliferating cells that are [[Radial glial cell|radial glia]]-like, preneuronal, and intermediate types, while not affecting early neuronal type cells; suggesting ethanol treatment alters the precursor cell pool. Furthermore, there is a greater decrease in differentiation and immature neurons than there is in proliferating progenitors, suggesting that the abnormal decrease in the percentage of actively dividing preneuronal progenitors results in a greater reduction in the maturation and survival of postmitotic cells.<ref name="pmid20534463"/>
Additionally, alcohol exposure increased several markers of cell death. In these studies neural degeneration seems to be mediated by non-apoptotic pathways.<ref name="pmid19554644"/><ref name="pmid20534463"/> One of the proposed mechanisms for alcohol’s neurotoxicity is the production of nitric oxide (NO), yet other studies have found alcohol-induced NO production to lead to apoptosis (''see [[#Neuroinflammation|Neuroinflammation]] section'').
==Transient versus stable alterations==
Many negative physiologic consequences of [[alcoholism]] are reversible during [[abstinence]]. As an example, long-term chronic alcoholics suffer a variety of cognitive deficiencies.<ref name="pmid25307576">{{cite journal |vauthors=Oscar-Berman M, Valmas MM, Sawyer KS, Ruiz SM, Luhar RB, Gravitz ZR |title=Profiles of impaired, spared, and recovered neuropsychologic processes in alcoholism |journal=Handb Clin Neurol |volume=125 |issue= |pages=183–210 |date=2014 |pmid=25307576 |pmc=4515358 |doi=10.1016/B978-0-444-62619-6.00012-4 |url=}}</ref> However, multiyear abstinence resolves most neurocognitive deficits, except for some lingering deficits in spatial processing.<ref name="pmid16930216">{{cite journal |vauthors=Fein G, Torres J, Price LJ, Di Sclafani V |title=Cognitive performance in long-term abstinent alcoholic individuals |journal=Alcohol. Clin. Exp. Res. |volume=30 |issue=9 |pages=1538–44 |date=September 2006 |pmid=16930216 |pmc=1868685 |doi=10.1111/j.1530-0277.2006.00185.x |url=}}</ref> Nevertheless there are some frequent long-term consequences that are not reversible during abstinence. Alcohol [[Craving (withdrawal)|craving]] (compulsive need to consume alcohol) is frequently present long-term among [[alcoholism|alcoholics]].<ref name="pmid15208171">{{cite journal |vauthors=Bottlender M, Soyka M |title=Impact of craving on alcohol relapse during, and 12 months following, outpatient treatment |journal=Alcohol Alcohol. |volume=39 |issue=4 |pages=357–61 |date=2004 |pmid=15208171 |doi=10.1093/alcalc/agh073 |url=}}</ref> Among 461 individuals who sought help for alcohol problems, followup was provided for up to 16 years.<ref name="pmid16445550">{{cite journal |vauthors=Moos RH, Moos BS |title=Rates and predictors of relapse after natural and treated remission from alcohol use disorders |journal=Addiction |volume=101 |issue=2 |pages=212–22 |date=February 2006 |pmid=16445550 |pmc=1976118 |doi=10.1111/j.1360-0443.2006.01310.x |url=}}</ref> By 16 years, 54% of those who tried to remain abstinent '''without''' professional help had relapsed, and 39% of those who tried to remain abstinent '''with help''' had relapsed.
Long-term, stable consequences of chronic alcohol abuse are thought to be due to stable alterations of [[regulation of gene expression#Regulation of transcription in addiction|gene expression]] resulting from [[epigenetics|epigenetic]] changes within particular regions of the brain.<ref name="pmid25131543">{{cite journal |vauthors=Krishnan HR, Sakharkar AJ, Teppen TL, Berkel TD, Pandey SC |title=The epigenetic landscape of alcoholism |journal=Int. Rev. Neurobiol. |volume=115 |issue= |pages=75–116 |date=2014 |pmid=25131543 |pmc=4337828 |doi=10.1016/B978-0-12-801311-3.00003-2 |url=}}</ref><ref name="pmid27780992">{{cite journal |vauthors=Jangra A, Sriram CS, Pandey S, Choubey P, Rajput P, Saroha B, Bezbaruah BK, Lahkar M |title=Epigenetic Modifications, Alcoholic Brain and Potential Drug Targets |journal=Ann Neurosci |volume=23 |issue=4 |pages=246–260 |date=October 2016 |pmid=27780992 |pmc=5075742 |doi=10.1159/000449486 |url=}}</ref><ref name="pmid28111764">{{cite journal |vauthors=Berkel TD, Pandey SC |title=Emerging Role of Epigenetic Mechanisms in Alcohol Addiction |journal=Alcohol. Clin. Exp. Res. |volume=41 |issue=4 |pages=666–680 |date=April 2017 |pmid=28111764 |pmc=5378655 |doi=10.1111/acer.13338 |url=}}</ref> For example, in rats exposed to alcohol for up to 5 days, there was an increase in histone 3 lysine 9 acetylation in the pronociceptin promoter in the brain amygdala complex. This acetylation is an activating mark for pronociceptin. The nociceptin/nociceptin opioid receptor system is involved in the reinforcing or conditioning effects of alcohol.<ref name="pmid22684622">{{cite journal |vauthors=D'Addario C, Caputi FF, Ekström TJ, Di Benedetto M, Maccarrone M, Romualdi P, Candeletti S |title=Ethanol induces epigenetic modulation of prodynorphin and pronociceptin gene expression in the rat amygdala complex |journal=J. Mol. Neurosci. |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=312–9 |date=February 2013 |pmid=22684622 |doi=10.1007/s12031-012-9829-y |url=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{alcohealth}} {{Psychoactive substance use}}
